III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4158
Section Intervention standards and prohibitions
Description (1) A child caring institution shall establish and follow written
policies and procedures that prohibit the following forms of
intervention:
(a) Any type of physical punishment including, but not limited to:
(ii) Hitting or striking, throwing, kicking, pulling, or pushing a
youth on any part of their body.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation On 8/25/25, a staff member bit a youth.
Investigation Youth A was interviewed face to face at the Juvenile Home
with MDHHS Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. Youth A reported
remembering the incident and having “Staff 1 making Youth A
mad”. Youth A reported Staff 1 wanted Youth A back in the
building and was “kicking an attitude” because Youth A believed
Staff 1 was being mean. Youth A reported Staff 1 sent “everyone”
down the hallway and when Youth A attempted to go down the
same hallway Staff 1 pushed and shoved Youth A to keep Youth
A from going down the hallway. Youth A reported responded by
pulling Staff 1’s hair and Staff 1 grabbed Youth A’s leg. Youth A
reported Staff 1 bit Youth A’s leg while Youth A was kicking Staff 1
and using Youth A’s leg to push down on Staff 1’s arm to keep
Staff 1 still. Youth A reported becoming more aggressive with Staff
1 after Staff 1 bit Youth A’s leg by pulling Staff 1’s hair harder.
Youth A reported a belief that Staff 1 was trying to protect and
defend herself by biting Youth A’s leg. Youth A reported another
staff (later identified as Staff 4) tried to pull Youth A off of Staff 1
but was unsuccessful. Youth A reported Staff 1 was crying so
Youth A called Staff 1 a “cry baby” which caused Staff 1 to “flip
Youth A off”. Youth A reported Supervisor placed Youth A in a
hold and took Youth A off of Staff 1, taking Youth A to another
unit. Youth A reported Law Enforcement came and took Youth A
to the hospital before removing Youth A to the Juvenile Home.
Youth A reported the two youth who went down the hallway with
2

Staff 2 and Staff 3 were Youth B and Youth C. Youth A reported
not trusting Staff 1 because Youth A reported Staff 1 pulled Youth
A’s hair a “couple of weeks ago” while Youth A was kicking Staff 1
on the shoulder. Youth A reported being pulled to the ground by
Youth A’s hair when Staff 1 was pulling Youth A’s hair during this
reported incident a “couple weeks ago”. Youth A reported
forgetting who might have seen this prior incident.
Administrator 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility
with MDHHS Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. He reported no issues with
Staff 1 and described Staff 1 as a “good staff who is sensitive and
often seeks support”. He reported there is no camera footage
because the camera covering that area of the incident was
recently broken by another youth and has yet to be replaced. He
reported Staff 1 is currently on “administration leave” until given
permission for her return to work. Administrator 1 was
interviewed again via phone with MDHHS Worker 1 on
9/11/2025. He reported the Aegis Behavior Management training
does not train staff on what to do if being held on the floor by a
youth. The focus has been staff holding a youth and when the
youth goes to the floor, staff are to disengage. He reported there
is an annual Aegis training coming up in a few weeks and he will
ask the trainers to address the hold in the incident and train staff
on how to respond. He reported the programs focus is to avoid
restraints whenever possible.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility with MDHHS
Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. She reported not being present at the
beginning of the incident but overheard Staff 1 call Supervisor to
inform him that Youth A was “amped up” and Staff 1 may need
help. She reported being in the process of gathering snacks for
the youth when Supervisor came to her location and both headed
towards the unit where Youth A was lodged. Supervisor received
another call, but Staff 2 is unaware what was said. Staff 2 reported
upon entering the unit and dropping off the snacks in the kitchen,
she went to the milieu and observed Staff 1 laying on the floor
yelling for help and having Youth A’s legs wrapped around Staff
1’s neck. Youth A was pulling the bun on the back of Staff 1’s
head and punching Staff 1 in the face and head. Staff 1 was lying
face down towards Youth A and Youth A was sitting facing Staff 1
with Youth A’s legs wrapped around Staff 1’s neck. Staff 4 was in
the office on the phone crying and Staff 3 was in the hallway with
Youth B and Youth C. Staff 2 reported Supervisor placed Youth A
in a hold and removed Youth A from holding and punching Staff 1.
Staff 2 assisted Staff 1 to the office and believed Staff 1 was
“really shook up”. Supervisor let go of Youth A and went into the
3

staff office locking the door. Youth A stood in front of the door
yelling that Youth A would kill Staff 1. Staff 2 described the
relationship between Youth A and Staff 1 as Youth A having
tension with Staff 1 and having assaulted Staff 1 at least four prior
times. She reported Youth A tends to conduct a “sneak attack”
when she is able to get Staff 1 alone. Staff 2 reported Staff 1
doesn’t yell at youth and described Staff 1 as “very kind, a leader,
someone who listens to the youth, and helps where she can”. She
also described that Staff 1 can be blunt but never disrespectful
and denied ever witnessing Staff 1 push, hit, kick, or bite Youth A.
Staff 3 was interviewed face to face at the facility with MDHHS
Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. She reported working on the unit during
the incident and taking Youth A outside before being instructed to
bring Youth A back inside. She reported Staff 1 was the
supervisor at the time and requested the youth return inside to
prepare for snacks, a movie, and bedtime. She reported Youth A
became upset, not wanting to return inside and wanted to speak
to Staff 1 about this issue. Staff 1 informed Youth A she would
speak with Youth A as soon as finished passing out medication.
Staff 3 reported Youth A threw a roll of toilet paper at Staff 1
because Youth A was unable to get Staff 1’s attention right away.
Staff 3 began clearing Youth B and Youth C from the milieu
because Youth A was becoming escalated. When looking out of
the hallway door window, Staff 3 reported observing Youth A
breaking the headphones of Youth C and Staff 1 going to pick up
the pieces so no youth could use them to self-harm. Staff 3
reported calling Supervisor at this time to inform him of the
situation. Staff 3 reported as Staff 1 threw the pieces down
another hallway (no youth in this hallway at the time) to keep them
away from youth, Youth A attacked Staff 1 while yelling Youth A
will kill Staff 1. Staff 3 reported Youth A got Staff 1 to the ground
before wrapping Youth A’s legs around Staff 1’s neck. Staff 4
attempted to remove Youth A from this hold but was unable to do
so and went to the office to call 911. Staff 3 reported the desk
blocked part of her view when Supervisor and Staff 2 came onto
the milieu. Staff 3 denied observing Staff 1 push, shove, or flip off
Youth A during the incident. Staff 3 described Youth A as disliking
authority and easily upset when told no. Youth A has ripped off
hair from Staff 1 in the past when upset and attacking Staff 1. Staff
3 described never observing Staff 1 being inappropriate with any
youth.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility with MDHHS
Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. She reported remembering the incident
began when Youth A was upset over having to return to the
4

building. She reported the plan for the evening was discussed at
the beginning of the shift and the plan was for all youth to return to
inside by 7:30pm. She reported when Youth A came inside,
Youth A asked Staff 1 to talk but Staff 1 informed Youth A she
“needed to wait a moment” and asked the other staff to speak
(Staff 3 and Staff 4) with Youth A. Youth A refused to speak to
Staff 3 and Staff 4 and walked around the milieu acting like Youth
A was becoming frustrated. Staff 1 reported going into the office to
put something down and hearing Youth A getting loud with Youth
C at which point Staff 1 called Supervisor to inform him Youth A
was becoming dysregulated. Staff 1 reported walking out of the
office and Youth A and Youth C became quiet. Staff 1 reported
Youth A yelled at Staff 1 in a “rude manner” and Staff 1 responded
with saying Youth A needs to talk with kind words, asking “what is
frustrating you”. Staff 1 reported Supervisor came on to the milieu
at this time and took Youth A aside before telling Staff 1, Youth A
is “calm and fine now”. Supervisor then left to assist Staff 2 in
another building. Staff 1 reported Youth B and Youth C were
getting anxious because Youth A was still speaking loudly while
walking around. Youth B and Youth C asked to go to the hallway
because of Youth A and Youth A asked what was going on. Staff
1 informed Youth A that both Youth B and Youth C get upset
when there is loud talking and Youth A is reported to have replied
“but I’m not getting violent”. Staff 1 reported Youth A picked up
Youth C’s ear buds, walked to the window in the door of the
hallway Youth C just went down and “started stomping on the ear
buds, breaking them into pieces”. Staff 1 reported telling Youth A
that Youth A would have to replace the ear buds per program
policy and Youth A responded with “I will not”. Staff 1 reported
walking over and picking up the broken pieces and throwing them
in an empty hallway so they could not be used for self-harm
(intention to pick them up later). Staff 1 reported as she closed the
door and turned back, Youth A ran towards her, grabbed Staff 1’s
bun (hair was tied up into a bun on the back of her head) and
pulled Staff 1 backwards. Youth A began to punch Staff 1 in the
face, so Staff 1 took off her glasses and threw them to the ground
to avoid the glasses being broken. Staff 1 reported her pants
began to fall down, so in an effort to grab her pants and pull them
up, she stopped struggling and tugged on her pants. It was at this
time, Youth A “swept Staff 1’s feet causing her to fall to the
ground. Staff 1 reported this is the first time a youth has taken her
to the ground during a physical altercation. Staff 1 reported while
on the ground she heard another staff (unable to identify who)
yelling for Youth A to stop. Youth A then placed Youth A’s legs
around the neck of Staff 1 and squeezing which caused Staff 1 to
“freak out”. Staff 1 reported not being able to breath and unable to
5

get Youth A to release the hold on Staff 1. Staff 1 reported biting
Youth A’s leg in an effort to make Youth A stop squeezing and not
allowing Staff 1 to breath. Staff 1 reported this worked because
Youth A “let Staff 1 free a little” and Staff 1 heard Staff 4 say Staff
4 can’t get Youth A off of Staff 1. Staff 1 reported yelling for Staff 4
to call 911. Staff 1 reported being able to get a hand and part of
her arm between her neck and Youth A’s leg, so Staff 1 was able
to move to a prone position. Staff 1 reported, Youth A continued to
punch Staff 1 in the head area while Staff 1 continued to “scream
and beg for help”. Staff 1 reported the next thing she knew was
seeing Staff 2’s hands grabbing Staff 1 and hearing a male’s
voice. It took a minute to get Youth A away from Staff 1 and when
feeling the release, Staff 1 got up with Staff 2’s assistance and
went into the office. Staff 1 reported once in the office; she heard
Youth A yelling that Youth A was going to “fucking kill you [Staff 1]
if I see you again”. Staff 1 reported a strong belief that she was
going to die and every time she pulled on Youth A’s leg, Youth A
would tighten Youth A’s leg hold causing Staff 1 to not get oxygen.
Staff 1 reported having a good working relationship with Youth A
even though Youth A can be very violent. Staff 1 denied pushing
or shoving Youth A during the incident. Staff 1 reported being
trained in physical behavior management but not trained in what
to do if a youth gets the staff to the ground. She reported training
covers standing holds with the idea that staff are to let go if the
youth goes to the floor. Staff 1 ended by reporting she is receiving
therapy for the trauma she experienced during the attack by Youth
A. Staff 1 was asked about the allegation of ever pushing, pulling
Youth A’s hair and flipping off Youth A. Staff 1 denied all of these
allegations.
Administrator 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility
with MDHHS Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. She reported being a trainer
in the Aegis Behavior Management technique. She reported staff
are taught to let go of a youth when the youth goes to the floor
during a restraint. She reported the Aegis Behavior Management
system does not address nor train what staff should do if a youth
has the staff on the floor as outlined in this incident. She reported
she will discuss this incident during the upcoming training in the
next few weeks. She reported not knowing what Staff 1 could
have done to get out of the hold Youth A had Staff 1 in at the time
even though she is a certified trainer.
Youth B was interviewed face to face at the facility with
MDHHS Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. Youth B reported feeling safe at
the facility with the exception of being attacked by Youth A. Youth
B reported staff will protect Youth B and intervene if Youth A
6

becomes dysregulated and aggressive. Youth B reported staff are
always present and very helpful. Youth B reported during the
incident, Youth B, Youth C, and Staff 3 were in the hallway to
avoid Youth A. Youth B reported being fearful of Youth A and
never observing Staff 1 do anything inappropriate during the
incident or any other time.
Youth C was interviewed face to face at the facility with
MDHHS Worker 1 on 9/4/2025. Youth C refused to be
interviewed.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed via phone with MDHHS
Worker 1 on 9/5/2025. She reported having no new information to
add but is hoping to obtain 5,000 dollars to bond out Youth A. She
reported the plan is to send Youth A back to the facility if Youth A
is bonded out of the juvenile home.
Staff 4 was interviewed via phone with MDHHS Worker 1 on
9/5/2025. She reported being present during the altercation with
Youth A. She reported spending time with Youth A outside and
came back inside with Youth A for dinner and chores before going
back outside. Staff 4 reported the youth were scheduled to return
inside at 7:30 pm as requested by Staff 1 for a movie and snacks.
Youth A didn’t want to come back inside and questioned Staff 1.
Staff 4 reported Staff 1 told Youth A to wait a minute and then they
could talk about it. Youth A got angry and began throwing things
towards Staff 1 before Staff 1 informed Youth A that this would
lead to a grounding the next day. Staff 4 reported taking Youth B
and Youth C into the hallway with Staff 3 because Youth A was
getting worked up. Staff 4 observed Youth A break the
headphones of Youth C in front of Youth C. She reported Staff 1
threw the broken headphone pieces in a place away from youth.
Staff 4 reported as Staff 1 was closing the door to the hallway she
threw the broken pieces into, Youth A grabbed Staff 1’s hair and
began punching Staff 1 in the face. Staff 4 reported trying to
intervene (used an open hand as a wedge) and getting Youth A
away from Staff 1 but was unable to do so. Staff 1 yelled for Staff
4 to call 911, which she did while Youth A got Staff 1 to the floor.
Staff 4 reported she was unable to see the altercation from the
office window but heard Staff 1 screaming for help. She reported
the scream sounded like someone in great fear. She reported
Staff 1 kept trying to verbally de-escalate Youth A but to no avail.
Finally, Supervisor and Staff 2 came into the milieu and
Supervisor was able to get Youth A off of Staff 1. Supervisor used
a one person hold. Staff 4 reported Youth A kept yelling that Youth
A wanted to kill Staff 1 or hoped she got sick and died. Staff 4
7

reported Staff 1 did nothing inappropriate and Youth A became
upset because Youth A couldn’t go back outside. Staff 1 only told
Youth A to wait a minute because Staff 1 was attending to other
youth at the time. Staff 4 believed there was a good relationship
between Staff 1 and Youth A. Staff 4 denied observing Staff 1
ever push or shove Youth A.
Supervisor was interviewed via phone with MDHHS Worker 1
on 9/11/2025. He reported being informed by Staff 1 that Youth A
had escalated and he suggested Staff 1 separate Youth A from
the other youth in the program. He reported telling Staff 1 to send
the youth present (Youth B and Youth C) to the “center” and put
herself (Staff 1) in the office to avoid confrontations with Youth A if
Youth A became aggressive. Supervisor reported receiving
another call from the unit and hearing “screaming” on the phone.
Supervisor reported observing Youth A with Youth A’s legs
wrapped around Staff 1’s neck and both lying on the floor when he
entered the milieu. Youth A was also holding Staff 1’s hair with
Youth A’s left hand and punching Staff 1 in the face and head with
Youth A’s right hand. He reported observing a bite mark on Youth
A’s thigh and the other youth (Youth B and Youth C) in the hallway
through the glass window on the hallway door. Supervisor
reported using the release technique of placing his hand over
Youth A’s hand that was holding Staff 1’s hair and pushing Youth
A’s hand into the hair so Youth A would no longer be pulling Staff
1’s hair. Once Youth A released Staff 1’s hair, Supervisor reported
placing Youth A in a seated one person hold until Staff 2 helped
Staff 1 get up and move to the office. Youth A was fighting the
hold Supervisor used but Staff 1 was able to get to the office.
Supervisor reported Staff 1 vomited once in the office and
appeared to be in “bad shape” physically. He reported not
knowing how Staff 1 could have gotten out of the hold Youth A
had Staff 1 in and reported being told by Staff 1 that Staff 1 bit
Youth A to get Youth A to release the hold around Staff 1’s neck.

Wedgwood Christian Services Significant Event Report dated
8/28/25 @ 7:35 pm. This document outlines the incident involving
the allegations of this investigation. Youth A is identified as the
youth involved with Staff 1, Staff 2, Staff 4, and Supervisor
9

identified as staff. The event type is documented as
Ambulance/Hospitalization, assault, Behavior Management, Police
contact, and Opened external Investigation. Event area is
documented as Client and Staff related. The event is described as
described by staff and youth interviewed. Youth A became upset
when asked to return to the building and after being told to wait a
minute while Staff 1 finished attending to other youth, Youth A
began to become dysregulated. It is documented that Staff 1
called Supervisor and was informed to clear the milieu of youth. At
this time, Youth A broke the headphones and attacked Staff 1 as
Staff 1 turned back to the milieu after throwing the broken
headphones down an empty hallway. Then it is documented
Youth A grabbed the hair of Staff 1 and drug Staff 1 around the
milieu before getting Staff 1 to the ground. Once on the ground
Youth A wrapped Youth A’s legs around the neck of Staff 1
attempted to choke Staff 1. Staff 4 attempted to intervene but
failed to remove Youth A. It is documented Staff 1 yelled for Staff
4 to contact 911 and Staff 4 left going to the office and calling 911.
It is documented that at this time, Staff 2 and Supervisor entered
the milieu. Supervisor placed Youth A into a one-person
emergency benevolent seated hold while Staff 1 went to the office.
Once all staff were in the office, Youth A stood outside of the door
telling the staff, Youth A would kill them while taunting Staff 1 who
was gagging. It is documented Law Enforcement showed up and
escorted Youth A to the hospital then Juvenile Home. Supervisor
is documented as debriefing with staff regarding the situation and
policies before leaving the unit. It is documented on this form that
all appropriate individuals (direct supervisor, on call Administrator,
Clinician, Case Manager, Nursing, MDHHS, Licensing, and
Police) were notified of the incident. The supervisor’s comments
document that in the future the existing behavior plan be followed
and youth and staff are proactive in separation along with other
measures such as calling Emergency Supervisor, home
supervisor, home clinician, and peer programs to aid in the de-
escalation prior to contacting law enforcement.
HR file for Staff 1 was reviewed, and it was found that Staff 1
was hired on 6/27/24. There is no documentation of any
disciplinary action in the file, and she is current on all required
trainings.
Kentwood Police Department Case Report dated 8/28/25 @
7:47 pm. This document outlines Law Enforcements investigation
of the incident outlined in the allegations. It is documented Law
Enforcement were informed by Staff 1 that Youth A had assaulted
Staff 1, choking Staff 1 to the point Staff 1 believed she would die.
It is documented Youth A admitted to assaulting Staff 1 and was
10

taken into Law Enforcement custody. Youth A was taken to the
hospital for evaluation and then lodged at the Kent County
Detention Center for Assault/Strangulation. Staff 1 reported the
incident began when Youth A punched her multiple times to the
head and face, before Youth A began kicking Staff 1 in the
stomach and arms. Youth A was able to pull Staff 1 to the ground
by Staff 1’s hair and once on the ground, Youth A wrapped Youth
A’s legs around Staff 1’s neck. Staff 1’s documented report
matches what she reported during her interview. Staff 1 also
reported biting Youth A in an “effort to live”. Youth A admitted to
hitting, kick, and pulling Staff 1’s hair and saying that Youth A will
kill Staff 1. Youth A also admitted having Youth A’s legs wrapped
around the neck of Staff 1 when Staff 1 bit Youth A’s leg. Youth A
reported using Youth A’s legs around the neck of Staff 1 to keep
Staff 1 on the floor. Youth A also reported to Law Enforcement the
incident started when Staff 1 talked disrespectfully to Youth A.
Youth A reported wanting to go down the hallway and Staff 1
blocked the hallway and pushed Youth A away from the doorway.
It is documented Staff 4 was also interviewed by Law
Enforcement. Staff 4 gave the same report that she presented in
interview for this report. She observed Youth A kicking, punching
and choking Staff 1. It is documented that Youth A was charged
with Felony Assault/Strangulation.
Wedgwood Christian Services Procedure Behavior
Management Procedures – Prohibited Techniques (03-16.2)
dated 9/10/2025. This document outlines the following behavior
management techniques as prohibited.
• Corporal or physical punishment, including hitting, striking,
throwing, kicking, pulling, pushing, pinching, slapping, hair
pulling, pressure points, mouth washing, sitting or standing
in a specific position, strenuous physical exercise or
threatening to use any of these methods.
• Threats of restraint, seclusion, punishment, or otherwise
suggesting physical or emotional harm to a youth.
• Verbal abuse, including use of profanity, derogatory or
discriminatory language, including negative references to a
youth’s background, appearance, diagnosis, health
condition, or mental state. Yelling, threats, ridicule,
humiliation, or sarcasm against a client are not allowed.
11

• Peer-on-peer discipline, which includes allowing peers to
punish, intimidate, fight, or harass another client.
• Individual staff members may not, without clinical guidance,
attempt to gain positive behavior from selected clients by
offering positive rewards or immunity from rules that could
be construed as bribery. Incentives and rewards may be
offered to individuals via special written programs. The
treatment team on a given shift may also offer spontaneous
incentives to the whole group for certain behavior, provided
that incentives don’t violate program or house rules or set
up client expectations that other members of the treatment
team would not be able or willing to fulfill.
• Use of time out or any type of room seclusion for reason of
inadequate staff coverage. (Note that in emergency
situations, some restrictions of movement may be
temporarily necessary in order to assure safety with
approval.)
• Group discipline for misbehavior of individuals, except in
accordance with Wedgwood’s established policies and
procedures.
• Denial of any essential program services as a punitive
consequence for client behavior. This includes:
o Depriving clients of meals or forcing them to eat
inedible or unprepared food.
o Denial of opportunity for at least 8 hours of sleep in a
24-hour period.
o Shelter, clothing, medical care, or essential personal
needs, including culturally specific items.
o Denial of therapeutic counseling sessions or
educational services.
o Denial of visits or communication with family, except
as specified in an Individual Program Modification on
which family and referring worker consultation has
been obtained. If a home visit or off grounds activity
is canceled due to a client’s behavior, staff members
12

are to offer opportunities for virtual, or on-campus
visits as an alternative.
• Any actions that could be construed as inhibiting a client’s
ability to achieve permanency.
• Mechanical restraint or use of any instruments causing
temporary incapacitation. Exceptions include mechanical
restraint applied by law enforcement personnel (not
Wedgwood staff members) when a truant resident is being
apprehended and returned for treatment; a client is
transported to or from ambulance during physical or
emotional crisis (mechanical restraint applied by trained
EMTs, not Wedgwood staff members). Any such restraint
must be removed as soon as the client is returned to the
treatment facility and behavior management can be safely
used.
• Chemical Restraint (as defined in Section 2b of 1973 PA
116, MCL 722.112b) and Noxious Substances, including,
but not limited to, pepper spray, tear gas, and mace.
• Excessive physical restraint: During physical restraint, only
as much force as is necessary to contain aggressive
behavior may be applied. This may only be done when all
other methods of de-escalation have been exhausted and
there is an immediate risk of serious harm to the client or
others should the behavior be allowed to persist.
• Any behavior management intervention found to produce
adverse side effects such as illness, severe emotional or
physical stress, or physical damage will be promptly
discontinued. Staff must continually monitor the client’s
physical and emotional condition and modify their
intervention at any point where the client appears at risk of
being physically or psychologically harmed.
• Restraint interventions specifically prohibited according to
MDHHS regulations include:
o Prone position (face down on floor)
o Placing upright clients face first directly against a
wall

The Aegis System Practicing Physical Skills Escape
Practices dated 2022. This document outlines techniques staff
can use to escape a hold by a youth. The only hold described in

This document does not address what staff should do once on the
